content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.```

user_context_message_data.about_model_message:
don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.

entries.snippet: Qwen 3 TTS lets you clone any voice for free, adds batch processing and long-form output, letting you produce polished multilingual audio without paid limits

entries.title: Best text-to-speech software of 2025
entries.snippet:
This document from TechRadar (dated September 29, 2025) presents a comprehensive guide to the best text-to-speech (TTS) software of 2025. It emphasizes the growing importance of TTS for accessibility, productivity, and content creation, particularly in media like YouTube and podcasting.

The top picks include:

1. **NaturalReader** – Best overall for personal/home use, offering 56 voices across 9 languages and cloud-based access.
2. **Murf** – Best for realistic AI voices, ideal for e-learning and presentations, with advanced editing and voice-changing tools.
3. **Amazon Polly** – Best for developers, offering easy API integration and broad language support.
4. **Play.ht** – Best for podcasting, providing nearly 600 voices in over 60 languages, with options tailored for commercial use.
5. **Voice Dream Reader** – Best for Mac and iOS users, offering 186 voices in 30 languages and compatibility with multiple cloud services.

The article also explains the difference between web-based TTS services and desktop software, discusses subscription models, and offers advice for integrating TTS into business workflows. Each software was rigorously tested based on performance, usability, voice quality, and pricing.

entries.title: ElevenLabs' AI Reader app can now narrate text in 32 languages
entries.snippet: ElevenLabs has globally launched its AI Reader text-to-speech app, expanding support to 32 languages, including Spanish, French, Arabic, Mandarin, and Hindi. Initially released in June in the US, UK, and Canada, the app is now available worldwide on iOS and Android. It allows users to listen to various text formats such as PDFs, articles, newsletters, and ePub files, though it does not support Kindle or Apple Books. The app offers a wide range of AI-generated voices, including those of deceased celebrities like Judy Garland and James Dean, with licensed usage approved by their heirs. The Reader app is free to use and doesn’t consume credits from ElevenLabs' main subscription plan. A premium version is in development, but the company assures a generous free tier will remain.

entries.title: Amazon Polly
Deep Voice: Real-time Neural Text-to-Speech
Claude's voice mode is now free for everyone - here's how to try it
entries.snippet:
Anthropic has introduced a free voice mode for its popular AI chatbot, Claude, accessible via its iOS and Android mobile apps. This new feature allows users to have spoken conversations with Claude, who responds audibly while also displaying key points on the screen. The voice mode supports five distinct voice styles—Buttery, Airy, Mellow, Glassy, and Rounded—and is currently available in English only.

Users can activate the feature by tapping the sound wave icon in the app and selecting their preferred voice. It is particularly useful in hands-free situations, such as commuting, cooking, or multitasking. To enhance the experience, it’s recommended to use the feature in quieter settings, speak naturally, and divide complex queries into smaller parts. Users can seamlessly switch between voice and text while maintaining conversation context. While similar to voice features in ChatGPT and Gemini Live, Claude’s voice mode stands out by being free for short sessions.

entries.title: Turn your laptop into an AI studio for less than $90 (88% off!)
entries.snippet: The article promotes a heavily discounted deal on 1ForAll AI's Lifetime Advance Plan, offering access to a suite of generative AI tools for $89.99, down from the original price of $792. The platform combines various AI features—text-to-speech, voice cloning, video generation, and image creation—into one subscription-free system. Compatible with providers like OpenAI, Azure, Google, and AWS, it allows users to generate natural-sounding speech, convert PDFs into audiobooks, and quickly create media content from simple data inputs (like Excel spreadsheets). It also supports commercial use and unlimited context, ideal for diverse applications from work presentations to marketing campaigns. Whether used professionally or personally, the deal enables users to build brand voices, create multilingual content, and produce videos with minimal technical effort. The promotion is offered via StackSocial, with pricing subject to change.

entries.title: Voice of the Revolution
entries.snippet:
The article "Voice of the Revolution" explores the rise and ubiquity of recorded and synthesized voices in our daily lives, noting how they span environments from online services to parking garages. It highlights that most voices we hear are not technically advanced synthesized ones, but rather “stored” human voices—recorded phrases played back as needed—used for simplicity and emotional warmth. Examples include Elwood Edwards of AOL’s “You’ve got mail,” Joni Bakum in parking ticket machines, and Joan Kenley as the voice of voice mail systems like Nortel’s Meridian Mail. Despite the technological possibilities, human voices are still preferred for their relatability and warmth.

The piece contrasts this with computer-generated speech, delving into the complexities and limitations of modern speech synthesis. It explains two main methods—concatenative (piecing together recorded phonemes) and parametric (fully artificial generation based on rules)—and shows their relative shortcomings in realism, especially in conveying natural prosody and emotion. While text-to-speech technology has valuable applications—in assistive tech, education, and navigation—it still lacks the comfort and authenticity of real human speech. The article closes with a philosophical musing on our uneasy but inevitable relationship with speaking machines.

entries.title: Voices of late actors Judy Garland, James Dean, Burt Reynolds, and more used in AI text-to-speech app
entries.snippet:
ElevenLabs, an AI audio company, has launched a new feature called "Iconic Voices" on its Reader App, allowing users to listen to books, articles, and essays narrated by AI-generated voices of late Hollywood legends such as Judy Garland, James Dean, Burt Reynolds, and Laurence Olivier. These voices were developed in collaboration with the celebrities' estates, including Liza Minnelli, who expressed excitement about preserving and expanding her mother Garland’s legacy through this technology.

The voices are exclusive to the Reader App and are intended for personal streaming use only, not for content creation or sharing. The app is currently available on iOS in select countries but will expand globally and to Android soon, alongside multilingual support.

This development comes amid broader debates about the use of AI-generated celebrity voices, highlighted by a recent controversy involving Scarlett Johansson and OpenAI. Johansson accused the company of using a voice similar to hers without consent, raising legal and ethical concerns. The issue of AI in entertainment was also part of SAG-AFTRA negotiations, leading to consent and compensation requirements for digital replicas of performers. Additional voices are expected to be added to the Iconic Voices library in the coming months.
